document_title: Peripheral neuropathy: Causes, symptoms and treatments
subsection_content:
1. Is it okay to delay treatment for peripheral neuropathy?
Peripheral neuropathy can worsen over time if left untreated, such as causing muscle atrophy, irreversible limb weakness, and reduced or loss of sensation in the skin areas that the peripheral nerves control. When 85% of the nerves have been damaged, it is very difficult to treat effectively and the chance of recovery is almost zero. Therefore, as soon as patients notice suspicious symptoms, they should go to the hospital for examination. for early diagnosis and treatment.
2. Why do pain symptoms appear for a while and then disappear on their own?
Some acute neurological diseases have symptoms that suddenly appear and then disappear. But after a while, the pain may return with more severe symptoms. This type of neuropathy is called chronic insidious progressive polyneuropathy. Sometimes, patients who increase their activity level will experience more burning.
3. How can I control the burning sensation in my feet and legs?
Many patients find relief from burning pain by using topical creams or Lidocaine patches.
Peripheral neuropathy can cause serious complications that affect appearance and long-term health, especially in people with diabetes. If treated properly, as well as well-managed risk factors/conditions, the patient will have a chance to recover and avoid unfortunate complications such as amputation in neurological diseases. Peripheral due to diabetes. For healthy people, in addition to practicing a healthy lifestyle, eating and living, you should have regular health check-ups to screen and help detect and treat diseases early.
